definitions: A small, often thoughtful, gift or gesture.
An unspecified small amount of something.
A treat or special item, usually food or drink.
Something of minor importance or value.
examples: I got you a little something for your birthday.
Here's a little something to thank you for your help.

definitions: Ready or likely to attack or confront.
Behaving in a forceful or determined way.
Characterized by hostility or forcefulness.
Pursuing one's aims and interests forcefully.
examples: The aggressive dog barked at everyone who walked by.
She has an aggressive style of negotiation that often gets results.

definitions: The branch of a nation's armed services that conducts military operations in the air.
A military organization primarily for airborne warfare.
The aviation branch of a country's military forces.
A national military organization for fighting in the air.
examples: He decided to join the air force after finishing high school.
The air force conducted a series of drills over the weekend.

definitions: An anxious awareness of danger.
A warning sound or device.
Sudden fear or distress caused by an awareness of danger.
A mechanism that gives a warning of a dangerous or unusual situation.
examples: The sudden noise caused alarm throughout the building.
Did you remember to set the alarm for 6 a.m.?

definitions: Everything is in a satisfactory state.
An expression of reassurance that there are no problems.
A phrase indicating that a situation is calm and under control.
Used to state that everything is fine or secure.
examples: Despite the storm, we checked the house and all is well.
The doctor called to say the test results are back and all is well.

definitions: In a state of disorder or disarray; scattered.
Everywhere; in many different locations.
Lacking a clear plan or focus; disorganized.
Exhibiting erratic or inconsistent behavior.
examples: His books and papers were all over the place.
Her thoughts seemed to be all over the place during the meeting.

definitions: An accredited diplomat sent by a country as its official representative to a foreign country.
A person who acts as a representative or promoter of a specified activity.
The highest-ranking diplomat who represents a state.
An official envoy, especially one of high rank.
examples: The French ambassador to the United States attended the event.
She is a brand ambassador for the new line of cosmetics.

definitions: A symbol used to point or indicate direction.
A slender stick with a sharp point, shot from a bow.
A mark or sign resembling an arrow, used to show direction.
A graphical symbol on a computer screen indicating position or options.
examples: Follow the red arrow on the sign to find the exit.
The archer released the arrow and it hit the target.

definitions: Having or revealing natural creative skill.
Relating to art or artists.
Aesthetically pleasing or done with skill and taste.
Characterized by a natural ability in art.
examples: She has a very artistic temperament and loves to paint.
The artistic design of the building was praised by critics.

definitions: Responsible for a mistake or wrongdoing.
Being the cause of an undesirable situation.
In the wrong; blameworthy.
Having made an error.
examples: The investigation determined that the other driver was at fault for the accident.
He was clearly at fault and had to apologize.

definitions: The land alongside or sloping down to a river or lake.
A stretch of rising land at the edge of a body of water.
The side of a river, stream, or canal.
An area of sloping ground bordering a river.
examples: We had a picnic on the grassy bank of the river.
The river overflowed its banks during the flood.

definitions: An arrangement made with a bank whereby one may deposit and withdraw money.
A financial account maintained by a bank for a customer.
A record of the financial transactions between a customer and a bank.
An account with a bank that allows for monetary deposits and withdrawals.
examples: She opened a new bank account to save for a car.
He transferred the money from his savings to his checking bank account.

definitions: A thing bought or offered for sale more cheaply than is usual or expected.
An agreement between two or more people or groups as to what each will do for the other.
Something acquired at a price advantageous to the buyer.
A discussion of the terms of an agreement.
examples: This coat was a real bargain at half price.
After some negotiation, they struck a bargain.

definitions: A headquarters or station for armed forces.
A place from which a military force operates.
A fortified place used as a center of operations.
An installation owned and operated by the military.
examples: The soldiers returned to the military base after their mission.
The naval base is located on the coast.

definitions: A broad inlet of the sea where the land curves inward.
A large body of water connected to an ocean or sea.
A recessed area or space in a room or building.
A compartment in an aircraft for carrying bombs or cargo.
examples: We sailed our boat across the bay.
The house has a beautiful bay window overlooking the garden.

definitions: To be pregnant.
To be anticipating the birth of one's child.
To be in the state of pregnancy.
A common phrase used to say that someone is going to have a baby.
examples: Sarah and Tom are expecting their first child in May.
She announced to her family that she was expecting.

definitions: Used to introduce a surprising but true statement.
A phrase indicating that what follows is unlikely but factual.
An expression used to emphasize the truth of an astonishing fact.
Said when telling someone about something that is true but seems improbable.
examples: Believe it or not, he managed to finish the entire project in one day.
She's 50 years old, believe it or not.

definitions: A hollow metal object, typically cup-shaped, that makes a ringing sound when struck.
An electrical device that makes a ringing sound.
The sound made by a bell.
Anything shaped like a bell.
examples: The church bell chimed at noon.
Please ring the front door bell when you arrive.

definitions: A long seat for several people, typically made of wood or metal.
A long, sturdy work table used by a carpenter or mechanic.
The seat on which a judge sits in a court of law.
The players on a sports team who are not currently playing in a game.
examples: They sat on a park bench and watched the ducks.
The mechanic placed the tools on his work bench.

definitions: To explode or cause to explode.
To inflate something with air, such as a tire or balloon.
To greatly enlarge a photograph.
To suddenly become very angry.
examples: The terrorists threatened to blow up the plane.
Could you help me blow up these balloons for the party?

definitions: Cooked in boiling water.
Having been heated to the point of boiling.
Subjected to the action of boiling liquid.
Food that has been prepared by boiling.
examples: I would like a hard-boiled egg for breakfast.
The recipe calls for boiled potatoes.

definitions: A device for slowing or stopping a moving vehicle, typically by applying pressure to the wheels.
To make a moving vehicle slow down or stop by using a brake.
Something that has a slowing or stopping effect.
The act of using a brake.
examples: He slammed on the brakes to avoid hitting the deer.
You need to brake gently on icy roads.

definitions: A local office or shop of a large company or organization.
A division or subdivision of a larger or more complex whole.
A part of a tree which grows out from the trunk.
A smaller stream or river that flows into a larger one.
examples: The bank has branches all over the country.
He works in the London branch of the company.

definitions: A small rectangular block of fired or sun-dried clay, used in building.
A rectangular-shaped object.
A reliable and helpful person.
The material from which bricks are made.
examples: The house was built with red bricks.
He bought a brick of cheese at the store.

definitions: A roughly cylindrical open container with a handle, used to carry things.
The amount that a bucket can hold.
A container for catching or holding liquid.
A scoop on a machine, used for digging or lifting.
examples: He filled the bucket with water from the well.
The children took a bucket and spade to the beach.

definitions: A small insect.
An error in a computer program or system.
A hidden microphone for listening to conversations.
A mild illness or infection.
examples: There's a bug crawling on the window.
I think I've caught a stomach bug.

definitions: An uncastrated adult male bovine animal.
The male of certain other large animals, such as the elephant and whale.
A person who buys shares of stock in expectation of a price rise.
Nonsense; foolish talk.
examples: The farmer led the bull out of the field.
He was being a bull in a china shop, making a mess of everything.

definitions: A number of things of the same type, growing or fastened together.
A group of people.
A large amount of something.
A set of keys.
examples: She picked a bunch of flowers from the garden.
A bunch of us are going to the movies tonight.

definitions: To suddenly start crying.
To begin to weep uncontrollably and abruptly.
To have a sudden emotional outbreak of crying.
To break down and cry unexpectedly.
examples: When she heard the sad news, she burst into tears.
The little boy burst into tears when he fell and scraped his knee.

definitions: To put or hide under ground.
To place a dead body in a grave.
To cover something or someone completely.
To involve oneself deeply in something.
examples: The dog buried its bone in the garden.
He was buried in the local cemetery.

definitions: A person whose trade is cutting up and selling meat in a shop.
A person who slaughters and prepares animals for food.
A person who has killed someone brutally.
To spoil something by doing it very badly.
examples: I bought some sausages from the local butcher.
The film director completely butchered the original novel.

definitions: A taxi.
The driver's compartment in a truck, bus, or train.
A horse-drawn carriage for public hire.
A shelter on a crane or other large machine for the operator.
examples: We took a cab to the airport.
The truck driver climbed into the cab.

definitions: A small wooden shelter or house in a wild or remote area.
A private room or compartment on a ship.
The area for passengers in an aircraft.
The driver's compartment in a truck or locomotive.
examples: They rented a cabin in the mountains for their vacation.
Please remain in your seats inside the cabin until the plane has stopped.

definitions: A complete list of items, typically one in alphabetical or other systematic order.
A publication containing a list of products available for purchase.
To make a systematic list of items of the same type.
A list of all the books or resources in a library.
examples: I ordered the shirt from a mail-order catalog.
The librarian is working to catalog all the new books.

definitions: A large underground chamber, typically of natural origin, in a hillside or cliff.
To give way or collapse.
To yield or submit under pressure.
A natural hollow in the earth.
examples: The explorers discovered a hidden cave in the mountainside.
The roof of the old mine finally caved in.

definitions: An official document attesting a certain fact.
A document confirming the successful completion of a course of study.
A document recording a fact such as birth, marriage, or death.
An official document giving details to show that something is true.
examples: She received a certificate for completing the training program.
You will need to show your birth certificate to get a passport.

definitions: To restore electrical energy to a battery or device.
To demand an amount as a price for a service rendered or goods supplied.
To formally accuse someone of something, especially an offense under law.
To rush forward in attack.
examples: I need to charge my phone before we leave.
How much do you charge for a haircut?

definitions: To register one's arrival at a hotel, airport, or event.
To report one's presence or arrival.
To drop off luggage for a flight.
To contact someone to make sure they are okay.
examples: We need to check in at the hotel before 3 PM.
You must check in your baggage at least an hour before your flight.

definitions: To settle one's hotel bill before leaving.
To leave a hotel after paying the bill.
To investigate or look at something interesting.
To borrow an item, such as a book, from a library.
examples: Guests must check out of the hotel by 11 a.m.
Let's check out that new restaurant tonight.

definitions: A friendly expression said just before you drink an alcoholic beverage.
An expression of good wishes, used as a toast.
Used to say thank you.
Used to say goodbye.
examples: They all raised their glasses and said, 'Cheers!'
'Here's that book you wanted.' 'Oh, cheers!'

definitions: Lacking affection or warmth of feeling; unemotional.
Of or at a low or relatively low temperature.
Not friendly or welcoming.
A common viral infection of the nose and throat.
examples: She gave him a cold stare.
It's cold outside, so wear a coat.

definitions: The part of a shirt, dress, coat, or blouse that fastens around or frames the neck.
A band of leather or other material put around the neck of a domestic animal.
To seize, grasp, or apprehend someone.
A connecting band on a pipe or shaft.
examples: He wore a shirt with a white collar.

definitions: To have an accident in a vehicle.
To make a sudden loud noise.
To fail suddenly, used for computers or systems.
To stay somewhere temporarily, especially overnight.
examples: The car crashed into a tree.
My computer crashed and I lost all my work.

definitions: A mark, object, or figure formed by two short intersecting lines or pieces (+ or ×).
The symbol of the Christian religion.
A mixture of two different things.
To go across or to the other side of something.
examples: She wore a small gold cross around her neck.
Put a cross in the box next to your choice.

definitions: The official department that administers and collects the duties levied by a government on imported goods.
The place at a port, airport, or frontier where officials check incoming goods, travelers, or luggage.

A traditional and widely accepted way of behaving or doing something that is specific to a particular society.
examples: We had to go through customs when we arrived in the country.

definitions: A social or romantic appointment or engagement.
A particular day of the month or year.
A sweet, dark brown, oval fruit with a stone.
The period of time to which an artifact or structure belongs.
examples: He asked her out on a date.
What's the date today?

definitions: A floor of a ship or boat.
A pack of playing cards.
A wooden platform built outdoors, attached to a house.
The equipment for playing recorded sound, such as a cassette deck.
examples: We went up on deck to get some fresh air.
Let's play a game of cards; do you have a deck?

definitions: To win a victory over someone in a battle, game, or other competition.
The state of having been defeated.
To prevent something from succeeding.
An instance of being defeated.
examples: Our team suffered a heavy defeat in the final match.

definitions: The supreme spirit of evil in Christianity and Judaism.
A wicked or cruel person.
A mischievous or reckless person.
Used for emphasis in questions or exclamations.
examples: In many religions, the devil is seen as the embodiment of evil.
Her little brother is a real devil, always getting into trouble.

definitions: A simplified drawing showing the appearance, structure, or workings of something.
A representation of a plan or scheme.
To represent something by means of a diagram.
A graphical representation of a concept or process.
examples: The diagram in the manual explains how to assemble the furniture.

definitions: Needing much effort or skill to accomplish, deal with, or understand.
Not easy to please or satisfy.
Problematic or troublesome.
Characterized by hardships or problems.
examples: He has a reputation for being a difficult person to work with.
This is a very difficult math problem.

definitions: Behaving or prone to behave in an untrustworthy or fraudulent way.
Intended to mislead or deceive.
Not honest; lying, cheating, or stealing.
Lacking in fairness and truthfulness.
examples: The dishonest salesman lied about the car's condition.
It was dishonest of him to take credit for my work.

definitions: A flat, thin, circular object.
A device for storing computer data.
A layer of cartilage separating the vertebrae in the spine.
A round, flat plate used in machinery.
examples: I saved the file to a floppy disk.
He has a slipped disk in his back.

definitions: The legal dissolution of a marriage by a court or other competent body.
A separation between things that were or ought to be connected.
To legally dissolve one's marriage with someone.
The ending of a marriage.
examples: They decided to get a divorce after five years of marriage.
The high rate of divorce is a major social issue.

definitions: Used to say that you do not know the answer to a question.
An informal way of stating that you are not the person to ask for information.
A phrase indicating a lack of knowledge or a desire not to answer.
Used to emphatically state one's ignorance about a subject.
examples: “What time does the store close?” “Don’t ask me, I've never been here before.”
Don't ask me why he did it; I have no idea.

definitions: Used to say that an experience was too bad, strange, or complicated to explain.
A way of saying you do not want to talk about something.
Implies that the story behind a situation is long or unpleasant.
A response indicating that a situation is too difficult or embarrassing to describe.
examples: “How was your day at work?” “Don't ask!”
She married and divorced a man in the same day? Don't ask.

definitions: Causing or involving great suffering, fear, or unhappiness; extremely bad or serious.
Of very low quality; very bad.
Extremely unpleasant.
Inspiring great dread or fear.
examples: The weather was dreadful all week.
He made a dreadful mistake.

definitions: To consume alcohol.
To take a liquid into the mouth and swallow.
A liquid for drinking.
To have a habit of drinking alcohol to excess.
examples: He doesn't drink alcohol.
Can I have a drink of water?

definitions: An internal or external device for storing and retrieving data on a computer.
To operate and control the direction and speed of a motor vehicle.
A trip or journey in a car.
An innate, biologically determined urge to attain a goal or satisfy a need.
examples: Make sure to save your work on the hard drive.
She has a strong drive to succeed.

definitions: A small round or pear-shaped portion of liquid that hangs or falls or adheres to a surface.
To let or make something fall vertically.
A fall in amount, quality, or value.
A small, round sweet.
examples: A drop of rain fell on her nose.

definitions: Affected by alcohol to the extent of losing control of one's faculties or behavior.
Having had too much alcohol to drink.
Caused by or relating to excessive consumption of alcohol.
A person who is drunk or who habitually drinks to excess.
examples: He got drunk at the party last night.

definitions: The joint between the forearm and the upper arm.
A piece of pipe bent at a sharp angle.
To push someone with one's elbow.
The part of a sleeve covering the elbow.
examples: He rested his elbow on the table.

definitions: A formal agreement to get married.
An arrangement to do something or go somewhere at a fixed time.
The action of engaging or being engaged.
A fight or battle between armed forces.
examples: They announced their engagement to their family.

definitions: To burst or shatter violently and noisily as a result of rapid combustion or decomposition.
To increase suddenly and rapidly in number or extent.
To show a violent emotion.
To disprove a theory or belief.
examples: The bomb could explode at any moment.

definitions: To develop a deep romantic or sexual attachment to someone.
To begin to feel love for another person.
To be captivated or charmed by someone.
To become infatuated with someone.
examples: They fell in love after meeting at a friend's party.
It is easy to fall in love with the beautiful scenery of the countryside.

definitions: To close or join securely.
To fix or hold in place.
To direct one's attention or gaze.
To attach something firmly.
examples: Please fasten your seatbelts.

definitions: A flying insect of a large order characterized by a single pair of transparent wings and sucking or piercing mouthparts.
To move through the air using wings.
To travel in an aircraft.
A flap of material covering the opening of a pair of trousers.
examples: A fly was buzzing around the room.
I need to learn how to fly a kite.

definitions: People in general.
Originating from the traditional culture of a country or community.
Relating to the traditional art or culture of a community.
One's family or relatives.
examples: The local folk are very friendly.
She enjoys listening to folk music.

definitions: A person who acts unwisely or imprudently; a silly person.
To trick or deceive someone.
A jester or clown in a medieval court.
A dessert made of puréed fruit mixed with cream or custard.
examples: I felt like a fool for believing his lies.
You can't fool me that easily.

definitions: For enjoyment or amusement, not for a serious purpose.
Done for pleasure rather than for any other reason.
As a form of entertainment.
Just for the sake of enjoyment.
examples: We decided to play a game of cards just for fun.
She started baking cakes for fun, but now it's her business.

definitions: For the simple enjoyment of doing something, without any other motive.
Simply for amusement or pleasure.
For the sake of entertainment and not for a serious reason.
Done purely for one's own enjoyment.
examples: I don't get paid for it; I just write my blog for the fun of it.
They decided to climb the hill just for the fun of it.

definitions: An organized body of military personnel or police.
Strength or energy as an attribute of physical action or movement.
Coercion or compulsion, especially with the use or threat of violence.
To make someone do something against their will.
examples: The government sent in a police force to control the riots.
The force of the explosion was incredible.

definitions: The part of the face above the eyebrows.
The area of the head between the hairline and the eyes.
The front part of the head.
The brow.
examples: He wiped the sweat from his forehead.
She has a high forehead.

definitions: Apt or likely not to remember.
Having a poor memory.
Characterized by a tendency to forget.
Negligent or neglectful.
examples: As he grew older, he became more forgetful.
I'm so forgetful, I left my keys at home again.

definitions: A building where motor vehicles are repaired.
A building for housing a motor vehicle or vehicles.
A type of popular music with a heavy, syncopated rhythm.
A place that sells fuel for motor vehicles.
examples: I need to take my car to the garage to get it fixed.

definitions: A hinged barrier used to close an opening in a wall, fence, or hedge.
The place in an airport where passengers go to get on their plane.
The number of people who pay to enter a sports ground or other venue.
A device that performs a basic logical operation in computing.
examples: Our flight is boarding at gate 23.

definitions: A chivalrous, courteous, or honorable man.
A man of good social position, especially one of wealth and leisure.
A polite or formal way of referring to a man.
A man who is polite and well-mannered.
examples: He was a true gentleman, always holding the door open for others.

definitions: To succeed in avoiding punishment for something.
To do something wrong or risky without being caught or punished.
To escape blame or punishment for a wrongdoing.
To manage to do something undesirable without being discovered.
examples: He cheated on the exam and thought he could get away with it.
I can't believe she managed to get away with telling such a lie.

definitions: To arrive at a place.
To enter a place, especially a building or vehicle.
To be elected to a political position.
To become involved in a difficult situation.
examples: What time does your train get in?
Quick, get in the car before it starts to rain.

definitions: An apparition of a dead person which is believed to appear or become manifest to the living.
A faint trace or slight possibility of something.
To end a personal relationship with someone by suddenly and without explanation withdrawing from all communication.
The soul or spirit of a dead person.
examples: Some people believe they have seen a ghost in the old house.
There wasn't a ghost of a chance that he would win.

definitions: An imaginary being of human form but superhuman size.
A person or thing of unusually great size, ability, or importance.
Of very great size or force; gigantic.
A star of relatively great size and luminosity.
examples: The story was about a friendly giant who lived in a castle.
That company is a giant in the tech industry.

definitions: To gradually become tired, old, calm, etc.
To pass into a specified state or condition over time.
To develop a particular quality or feeling.
To undergo a gradual change to a new state.
examples: As the day went on, the children began to grow tired.
He grew calm after hearing the good news.

definitions: To wait or spend time somewhere, usually doing nothing.
To loiter or wait around without any clear purpose.
To stay in a place longer than is necessary.
To associate with someone.
examples: They were just hanging around the street corner.

definitions: To spend a lot of time in a place or with someone.
To relax and do nothing in particular.
To display something, such as laundry, on a line.

examples: The kids like to hang out at the mall on weekends.
We're just going to hang out at my place tonight.

definitions: A place on the coast where vessels may find shelter, especially one protected from rough water.
To keep a thought or feeling, typically a negative one, in one's mind, especially secretly.
To give a home or shelter to.
A port or haven for ships.
examples: The ships were safe in the harbor during the storm.

definitions: In some religions, the place where God or the gods are believed to live and where good people are believed to go when they die.
A place or state of supreme happiness.
The sky, especially as seen from the earth.
A place of great comfort and pleasure.
examples: She believes that her grandmother is in heaven.
Lying on the beach in the sun is my idea of heaven.

definitions: The back part of the human foot below the ankle.
The part of a shoe or stocking that covers the heel.
An inconsiderate or untrustworthy person.
The end of a loaf of bread.
examples: I have a blister on my heel.
The heel of her shoe broke.

definitions: In some religions, a place of evil and suffering where the wicked are punished after death.
A state or place of great suffering; an ordeal.
Used for emphasis, especially to express anger or surprise.
A situation of extreme difficulty and unpleasantness.
examples: The final exams were hell.

definitions: An intense feeling of fear, shock, or disgust.
A thing causing such a feeling.

Intense dismay.
examples: She watched in horror as the building collapsed.
I love watching horror movies, even though they scare me.

definitions: To pursue and kill a wild animal for sport or food.
To search determinedly for someone or something.
The act of hunting.
To chase or pursue.
examples: Lions often hunt in groups.

definitions: To move or act more quickly.
To cause someone to move or act more quickly.
An expression used to urge someone to be faster.
To speed up a process.
examples: Hurry up, or we'll be late for the movie!

definitions: A small, simple, single-story building or shelter.
A crude or primitive dwelling.
A temporary shelter for soldiers or campers.
A small shed or cabin.
examples: They lived in a small wooden hut in the forest.

definitions: Not conforming to accepted standards of morality.
Not morally good or right; wicked.
Violating moral principles.
Corrupt or unethical.
examples: Many people consider lying to be immoral.

definitions: Crying or weeping.
In the state of shedding tears.
Visibly upset and crying.
With tears in one's eyes.
examples: She was in tears after hearing the bad news.

definitions: The first letter of a name or word.
Existing or occurring at the beginning.
The first stage of a process.
To mark or sign with one's initials.
examples: He carved his initials into the tree.

definitions: To speak to or treat with disrespect or scornful abuse.
An offensive or disrespectful remark or action.
To cause offense to someone.
A remark or action that is insulting.
examples: He was fired for insulting a customer.

definitions: An arrangement by which a company provides a guarantee of compensation for specified loss, damage, illness, or death in return for payment of a premium.
A thing providing protection against a possible eventuality.
The business of providing insurance.
The amount for which something is insured.
examples: It is important to have car insurance before you drive.

definitions: A strong, hard magnetic silvery-gray metal.
A handheld implement with a flat steel base that is heated to smooth clothes.
To smooth clothes with an iron.
A club used in golf for hitting the ball.
examples: The gate was made of iron.

definitions: To run at a steady, gentle pace, especially on a regular basis as a form of exercise.
To nudge or push slightly.
To stimulate someone's memory.
A spell of jogging.
examples: I like to jog in the park every morning.

family: to make a sudden movement (in fright)
definitions: To push oneself off a surface and into the air by using the muscles in one's legs and feet.
To make a sudden, startled movement.
To move quickly and suddenly.
An act of jumping.
examples: The loud noise made me jump.

definitions: A body of people sworn to give a verdict in a legal case on the basis of evidence submitted to them in court.
A group of people selected to decide the winner of a competition.
A panel of judges.

definitions: To make a garment or other item by interlocking loops of wool or other yarn with knitting needles or on a machine.

To make a frowning expression.
A knitted fabric.
examples: My grandmother taught me how to knit a scarf.

definitions: A device that emits light through a process of optical amplification based on the stimulated emission of electromagnetic radiation.
A narrow and intense beam of light.

To enhance the features, figure, or character of someone.
A set of outer clothes made of the same fabric and designed to be worn together.
A lawsuit.
examples: That color really suits you.
Does Friday at 3 p.m. suit you for a meeting?

definitions: To use offensive language, especially as an expression of anger.
To make a solemn statement or promise undertaking to do something or affirming that something is the case.
To take an oath.
To have great confidence in something.
examples: It's not polite to swear.
I swear I will never lie to you again.

definitions: To clean an area by brushing away dirt or litter with a broom.
To move swiftly and smoothly.
To search an area.
A long, sweeping movement.
examples: She swept the floor after dinner.
A new craze is sweeping the nation.

definitions: A weapon with a long metal blade and a hilt with a hand guard, used for thrusting or striking.
A long, sharp-edged weapon.
Something that has the power to harm or destroy.
A symbol of military power.
examples: The knight drew his sword and prepared for battle.
The pen is mightier than the sword.

definitions: The hindmost part of an animal, especially when prolonged beyond the rest of the body.
The rear part of an airplane.
To follow and observe someone closely, especially in secret.
The final, more distant, or less important part of something.
examples: The dog wagged its tail happily.
The detective decided to tail the suspect.

definitions: To do something that might have a negative or dangerous result.
To expose oneself to a chance of loss or harm.
To gamble or take a chance on something.
To proceed with an action despite the possibility of an adverse outcome.
examples: He decided to take a risk and start his own business.
Sometimes you have to take a risk to achieve great things.

definitions: To go with someone to a restaurant, movie, or other social event, and usually pay for them.
To remove something from a place.
To kill or disable someone.
To obtain an official document or service.
examples: He's taking his girlfriend out for her birthday.
Please take out the trash before you leave.

definitions: A device by which a flow of liquid or gas from a pipe or container can be controlled.
To strike someone or something with a quick, light blow.
A quick, light blow.
To draw liquid from a cask, barrel, or other container.
examples: Please turn off the tap when you are finished.
She tapped him on the shoulder to get his attention.

definitions: A building devoted to the worship, or regarded as the dwelling place, of a god or gods or other objects of religious reverence.
The flat part of either side of the head between the forehead and the ear.
A place of worship.
A building dedicated to religious or spiritual activities.
examples: The ancient temple was built on a hilltop.
He had a throbbing pain in his left temple.

definitions: An area of land under the jurisdiction of a ruler or state.
An area defended by an animal or group of animals against others of the same species.
An area in which one has rights, responsibilities, or knowledge.
A region or district.
examples: The country is fighting to protect its territory.
The cat marked its territory.

definitions: Extreme fear.
The use of violence and intimidation in the pursuit of political aims.
A person or thing that causes extreme fear.
A state of intense fear.
examples: She screamed in terror when she saw the spider.
The reign of terror lasted for several years.

definitions: To bind someone's arms and legs so they cannot move.
To fasten something with a rope or cord.
To occupy someone's time so they are not available for other activities.
To invest money so that it is not easily available for use.
examples: The robbers tied up the security guard.
I'm tied up in meetings all day.

definitions: A series of contests between a number of competitors, who compete for an overall prize.
A competition for teams or single players in which a series of games is played.
A medieval pageant in which knights competed on horseback.
A series of games or contests that make up a single competition.
examples: Our school's basketball team won the championship tournament.
She is competing in a chess tournament this weekend.

definitions: A prepared course or circuit for racing, running, or other sports.
A mark or line of marks left by a person, animal, or vehicle in passing.
To follow the course or trail of someone or something.
A song or piece of music on a record, CD, or digital playlist.
examples: He is a star athlete on the track team.
The police tracked the suspect to his hiding place.

definitions: An event causing great suffering, destruction, and distress, such as a serious accident, crime, or natural catastrophe.
A play dealing with tragic events and having an unhappy ending, especially one concerning the downfall of the main character.
A disastrous event.
A story with a sad or unhappy ending.
examples: The earthquake was a terrible tragedy for the entire country.
Shakespeare's 'Hamlet' is a classic tragedy.

definitions: A plane figure with three straight sides and three angles.
A percussion instrument consisting of a steel rod bent into a triangle, open at one corner.
A group of three related people or things.
A three-sided polygon.
examples: A triangle has three sides and three angles.
She played the triangle in the school orchestra.

definitions: A long, hollow cylinder of metal, plastic, glass, etc., for holding or conveying liquids or gases.
The underground electric railway system in London.
A flexible container for a semiliquid substance.
A television set.
examples: I squeezed the last bit of toothpaste out of the tube.
We took the tube to get across London.

definitions: Not wearing clothes; naked.
To take off one's clothes.
Without a dressing or sauce.
In a state of being unclothed.
examples: He got undressed and went to bed.
I prefer my salad undressed.

definitions: To open and remove the contents of a suitcase, bag, or container.
To remove something from a packed container.
To analyze something into its component elements.
To take things out of a bag or box.
examples: The first thing I do when I get to a hotel is unpack my suitcase.
Let's unpack the groceries and put them away.

definitions: A medium-sized motor vehicle, typically without side windows in the rear part, for transporting goods.
The forefront of a movement or trend.
A covered vehicle for transporting goods or people.
A large, box-like vehicle.
examples: The delivery company uses a fleet of vans.
They helped him move his furniture in a van.

definitions: Writing arranged with a metrical rhythm, typically having a rhyme.
A group of lines that form a unit in a poem or song; a stanza.
One of the short numbered divisions of a chapter in the Bible.
A line of poetry.
examples: She wrote a beautiful verse for her mother's birthday card.
I only remember the first verse of the song.

definitions: A thing designed or used for inflicting bodily harm or physical damage.
A means of gaining an advantage or defending oneself.
An instrument of attack or defense.
Something used to injure, defeat, or destroy.
examples: The police found the murder weapon in the river.
His sharp wit is his most effective weapon.

definitions: A network of fine threads constructed by a spider from fluid secreted by its spinnerets, used to catch its prey.
A complex system of interconnected elements; a network.
The World Wide Web.
The membrane between the toes of a swimming bird or other aquatic animal.
examples: A spider was spinning a web in the corner of the room.
The company has a complex web of international suppliers.

definitions: A cereal plant that is the most important kind grown in temperate countries, the grain of which is ground to make flour for bread, pasta, pastry, etc.
The grain of the wheat plant.
A light yellow-brown color.
A type of cereal crop.
examples: The fields were full of golden wheat.
Bread is made from wheat flour.
